pageData.text: In this investigation, students will investigate the basic principles of inheritance by growing and observing corn seedlings. Two characteristics, stem color and leaf plant height, will be observed in this lab exercise. The seedlings are generated from albino-green hybrid self-pollination and reveal that albinism is recessive. Students will collect and analyze data and make predictions about the parent plant and discuss the mode of inheritance.

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Preparation - 30 minutes
Activity 1: Planting - 30 minutes
Activity 2: Scoring - 30 minutes
Activity 3: Data Analysis and Chi-Square Test - 15 minutes
Activity 4: Non-Lethal vs. Lethal Traits Observations - 30 minutes
pageData.desc:
Preparation - 30 minutes
Activity 1: Planting - 30 minutes
Activity 2: Scoring - 30 minutes
Activity 3: Data Analysis and Chi-Square Test - 15 minutes
Activity 4: Non-Lethal vs. Lethal Traits Observations - 30 minutes

pageData.text: Activity 2 (Scoring) should follow Activity 1 (Planting) by 7–10 days. Between activities, monitor the plants daily and water them every other day or as necessary. To observe non-lethal versus lethal traits, the plants should continue to be monitored for an additional 2–5 days.

pageData.subTitle: Overview video: Mendelian Genetics with Corn

pageData.text: Mendelian genetics is based on seven pea plant traits that Gregor Mendel studied for decades. Mendel discovered that these traits are either or . One of the traits that Mendel observed was pea seed color - green (recessive) or yellow (dominant). In 2007, researchers identified the pea color gene, sgr, that Mendel was ultimately tracking. When seeds are yellow, the sgr gene turns on, synthesizing a protein that breaks down the green pigment, chlorophyll. Green seeds have a non-functional sgr gene, thus the chlorophyll remains in the seed, which appears green.

Skin color in humans is not inherited as simply as seed color in Mendel’s pea plants. Skin color is a polygenic characteristic, meaning it is affected by many different genes. Children will not always have the same skin tone as their parents. Other polygenic traits include hair color and height. In fact, most traits are affected by a combination of multiple genes and the environment. Mendel was fortunate that he studied non-polygenic traits: if they were polygenic, he may have never started to unlock the secrets of inheritance.

pageData.desc: Five members of a family that each have a different skin tone.
pageData.altText: Five members of a family that each have a different skin tone.

pageData.text: The modern understanding of genetic inheritance is based, in part, on the research of Gregor Mendel (1822–1884), an Austrian monk who performed carefully controlled studies of trait inheritance in pea plants. As Mendel worked with peas, he discovered patterns in the physical traits in different generations of offspring. An example is seed color (yellow or green) or seed texture (wrinkled or smooth). These traits were passed from generation to generation in predictable patterns. Based on his findings, Mendel developed two important laws: the <button class='glossary-text'>law of segregation</button> and the <button class='glossary-text'>law of independent assortment</button>.

Mendel’s first law, the law of segregation, states that individuals possess two <button class='glossary-text'>alleles</button> for each trait. When organisms are crossed, the offspring randomly receive one allele from each parent for a particular trait. Alleles are different forms of the same gene that code for slightly different expression patterns of a genetic trait. The two alleles may or may not be identical. When two different alleles are present, the trait that is expressed is <button class='glossary-text'>dominant</button>; the allele that is not expressed is <button class='glossary-text'>recessive</button>. In one of Mendel’s experiments, the tall parent plant was <button class='glossary-text'>homozygous dominant</button>, meaning that both of its alleles were for the “tall” trait. The short parent plant was <button class='glossary-text'>homozygous recessive</button> because it possessed two matching “short” alleles. All the offspring in the first generation were <button class='glossary-text'>heterozygous</button> and had one “tall” allele and one “short” allele (e.g., tall/short). The heterozygous <button class='glossary-text'>genotype</button> resulted in expression of the dominant trait, which was the tall <button class='glossary-text'>phenotype</button>.

At the time Mendel was working, there were multiple hypotheses for the mechanism of inheritance. However, terms such as phenotype, the physical expression of a trait, and allele, the genetic traits, which combine to create an individual’s genotype, did not exist. The use of these terms throughout this manual is a result of the “Modern Evolutionary Synthesis,” which combined the 19th century work of Charles Darwin and Gregor Mendel with 20th century theories of the molecular mechanisms of inheritance.

Mendel’s second law, the law of independent assortment, says that all traits are inherited independently of one another. This means that wrinkled seeds will not always be yellow, and smooth seeds will not always be green. Instead, seeds can be yellow and wrinkled, green and wrinkled, yellow and smooth, or green and smooth. Mendel’s laws help explain heredity (which traits are passed from one generation to the next) and variation (the differences between parents and their offspring).

The genetic information for a specific trait is usually written with the same letter of the alphabet representing both <button class='glossary-text'>alleles</button>. An uppercase (capital) letter represents the <button class='glossary-text'>dominant</button> allele, and a lowercase letter denotes the <button class='glossary-text'>recessive</button> allele. The two alleles written together represent the <button class='glossary-text'>genotype</button> of an organism. For example, the genotype of a tall, <button class='glossary-text'>homozygous-dominant</button> parent can be written as TT, whereas the genotype of a short, <button class='glossary-text'>homozygous-recessive</button> parent can be written tt. The genotype of the first generation of offspring includes one allele from each parent and is denoted as Tt. The outward expression of genotype is the <button class='glossary-text'>phenotype</button>. This is what we see when we examine an organism. For example, the tall, first-generation pea plants in Mendel’s experiment exhibited the tall phenotype and the Tt genotype.

The first two organisms that are crossed are called the <button class='glossary-text'>Parental generation (P generation)</button>. All descendants of the P generation are part of the <button class='glossary-text'>Filial generation (F generation)</button>. Offspring of the P generation are F<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub>. The F<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub> offspring can be bred to each other, which in turn produce F<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub>, which then produce F<sub class='bodysubscript'>3</sub>, etc. When only one set of traits is being tracked in a cross, it is a monohybrid cross (i.e., if we are only interested in flower color). A cross that involves two sets of alleles is a dihybrid cross (i.e., tracking flower color and seed texture); see Figure 1).

pageData.desc: Figure 1: dihybrid cross with potential F2 generation phenotypes when parents are heterozygous.
pageData.altText: Figure 1: dihybrid cross with potential F2 generation phenotypes when parents are heterozygous.

pageData.question: If one parent is homozygous dominant for a gene and the other is homozygous recessive for the same gene, what is the probability that one of their offspring will be heterozygotic?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: There is a 100% probability that any individual in the F<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub> generation will be heterozygotic.

pageData.question: If one parent is homozygous dominant for a gene and the other is homozygous recessive for the same gene, what is the probability that one of their offspring will be homozygous?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: There is a 0% probability that any individual in the F<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub> generation will be homozygotic.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The first two organisms that are crossed are called the parental generation (P generation). All descendants of the P generation are part of the filial generation (F generation). Offspring of the P generation are F<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub>. The F<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub> offspring can be bred to each other, which in turn produce F<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub>, which then produce F<sub class='bodysubscript'>3</sub>, etc. When only one set of traits is being tracked in a cross, it is a monohybrid cross (i.e., if we are only interested in flower color). A cross that involves two sets of alleles is a dihybrid cross (i.e., tracking flower color and seed texture).  Punnett squares can also be used to calculate the probability of an offspring having a given genotype, or to calculate the expected distribution of genotypes in the F<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub> and F<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub> generations.

img.alt: Figure 1: dihybrid cross with potential F2 generation phenotypes when parents are heterozygous.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The first two organisms that are crossed are called the parental generation (P generation). All descendants of the P generation are part of the filial generation (F generation). Offspring of the P generation are F<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub>. The F<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub> offspring can be bred to each other, which in turn produce F<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub>, which then produce F<sub class='bodysubscript'>3</sub>, etc. When only one set of traits is being tracked in a cross, it is a monohybrid cross (i.e., if we are only interested in flower color). A cross that involves two sets of alleles is a dihybrid cross (i.e., tracking flower color and seed texture).  Punnett squares can also be used to calculate the probability of an offspring having a given genotype, or to calculate the expected distribution of genotypes in the F<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub> and F<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub> generations.

img.alt: Figure 1: dihybrid cross with potential F2 generation phenotypes when parents are heterozygous.

pageData.text: A table called a <button class='glossary-text'>Punnett square</button> can be used to show the results of genetic crosses. This useful tool was named for Reginald Punnett (1875–1967), a Cambridge biologist who verified and expanded on Mendel’s work. To draw a Punnett square, write one set of parental <button class='glossary-text'>alleles</button> across the top of the grid, and write the other set of alleles vertically down the left-hand side of the grid. For a monohybrid cross, each parental allele is listed separately in a column or row. Each box in the Punnett square represents a specific combination of parental alleles and is determined by column and row placement. Fill in each box by writing the allele for the column and the allele for the row side-by-side. Refer to Figure 2, which shows how to draw a Punnett square for a monohybrid cross.

Before conducting studies on inheritance, biologists typically establish true-breeding (homozygous) stocks for the traits they are interested in studying. For most controlled genetic studies, the individuals in the <button class='glossary-text'>P generation</button> will be homozygous for the traits in question. In this lab, you will only be growing seeds from Parent 1 of the P generation.  These seeds are labeled P<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub> for Parent 1.  You will use Punnett squares to predict the <button class='glossary-text'>genotype</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>phenotype</button> of the other parent, Parent 2 (P<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub>) as well as the offspring.

pageData.desc: Figure 2: Figure describing the steps of building a Punnett square
pageData.altText: Figure 2: Figure describing the steps of building a Punnett square

pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Punnett squares</button> can also be used to calculate the probability of an offspring having a given <button class='glossary-text'>genotype</button>, or to calculate the expected distribution of genotypes in the F<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub> and F<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub> generations. For instance, in the cross demonstrated in <button class='resource-text'>Figure 2</button>, one parent is homozygous <button class='glossary-text'>dominant</button> for the gene in question (AA) and the other is <button class='glossary-text'>homozygous recessive</button> for the same gene (aa). Completing the cross in the Punnett square shows that all possible combinations of <button class='glossary-text'>alleles</button> will result in a <button class='glossary-text'>heterozygous</button> individual. There is a 100% probability that any individual in the F<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub> generation will have the genotype Aa. Said another way, we would expect 100% of the offspring to have the genotype of Aa. If the F<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub> generation are crossed back to each other the cross would be expressed as seen in Figure 3. To calculate the probability that an individual offspring will have a particular genotype, add the number of times that genotype appears in the table and divide by the total number of possibilities (Table 1). In this case, Aa appears twice; so, two divided by four is 0.5, giving us a 1/2 (1:2) probability that any given offspring will be Aa. We would also expect that 50% of the offspring in that generation will have that genotype. Similarly, AA and aa only appear once. One divided by four is 0.25, so 25% of the offspring will have either of those genotypes; see Table 1. Since the combination of genes during mating is a mostly random occurrence, actual percentages may vary in real populations, but the larger the population is, the closer to these ratios the data will be.

pageData.desc: Figure 3: Punnett square showing the result of an F1 cross
pageData.altText: Figure 3: Punnett square showing the result of an F1 cross

pageData.text: Probabilities for multiple genes can be calculated by multiplying the probabilities of each together. If pea plants homozygous for the tall gene (TT) and homozygous for the yellow pea gene (YY) were crossed with plants for both traits (TtYy) (Figure 4), the crosses would each result in 50% and 50% heterozygotes (Table 2). To determine the expected percentage of TTYY individuals in the F1 generation, the odds of TT (0.5) are multiplied by the odds of YY (0.5), yielding a probability of 0.25 or 25% ().

pageData.desc: Figure 4: Punnett squares showing results for the height gene and the seed color gene
pageData.altText: Figure 4: Punnett squares showing results for the height gene and the seed color gene

pageData.text: The seeds in this kit were derived by self-pollinating heterozygous plants carrying the <button class='glossary-text'>allele</button> for chlorophyll deficiency. The genetic ratio of 3 green:1 albino <button class='glossary-text'>phenotypes</button> is predicted.

Cystic fibrosis and achondroplasia are recessively lethal for humans, like albinism is for corn. Achondroplasia is a bone disorder that causes dwarfism and can be inherited as an autosomal <button class='glossary-text'>dominant</button> trait. While the inheritance of one achondroplasia allele can cause the disease, the inheritance of two achondroplasia alleles is fatal within a few months of birth.

pageData.question: If one parent has the genotype TtYy and the other is homozygous dominant for the same genes, what is the probability that one of their offspring will be heterozygotic for both traits?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: There is a 25% probability that any individual in the F<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub> generation will have the <button class='glossary-text'>genotype</button> TtYy.

pageData.question: If one parent has the genotype TTYy and the other has the genotype Ttyy, what is the probability that one of their offspring will have the genotype ttyy?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: There is a 0% probability that any individual in the F<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub> generation will be <button class='glossary-text'>homozygous recessive</button> for both genes.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Probabilities for multiple genes can be calculated by multiplying the probabilities of each genotype together. Let’s use two pea plants as an example: one pea plant homozygous for both the tall gene (TT) and the yellow pea gene (YY) is crossed with a plant heterozygous for both traits (TtYy). Taking each gene into account separately, any offspring has a 50% chance of being either homozygous dominant or heterozygous for each gene. To determine the expected percentage of TTYY individuals in the F<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub> generation, the odds of TT (0.5) are multiplied by the odds of YY (0.5) yielding a probability of 0.25 or 25%.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Probabilities for multiple genes can be calculated by multiplying the probabilities of each genotype together. Let’s use two pea plants as an example: one pea plant homozygous for both the tall gene (TT) and the yellow pea gene (YY) is crossed with a plant heterozygous for both traits (TtYy). Taking each gene into account separately, any offspring has a 50% chance of being either homozygous dominant or heterozygous for each gene. To determine the expected percentage of TTYY individuals in the F<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub> generation, the odds of TT (0.5) are multiplied by the odds of YY (0.5) yielding a probability of 0.25 or 25%.

pageData.desc: A procedural workflow for the investigation. Before beginning, you will need to prepare the substrate, predict the genetic ratios of the offspring and soak the seeds overnight. In Activity 1, you will mix the substrate and water. Then, you will add the substrate to the cups, add the seeds and place the cups in sunlight to monitor. Next, you will photograph the cups. In Activity 2, you will measure the seedling heights and photograph the seedlings. In Activity 3, you will determine the expected ratio and calculate the expected ratio of the seedlings. Then, you will determine the Chi-squared value. Next, you will calculate the degrees of freedom and accept or reject the null hypothesis. In Activity 4, you will continue to observe the seedlings. Once 14 days have elapsed, you will record the days of survival for each plant and photograph the seedlings.

Then, you will determine the Chi-squared value. Next, you will calculate the degrees of freedom and accept or reject the null hypothesis. In Activity 4, you will continue to observe the seedlings. Once 14 days have elapsed, you will record the days of survival for each plant and photograph the seedlings.

pageData.text: Reorder Information: A replacement investigation kit for Mendelian Genetics with Corn (item number 580109) can be ordered from Carolina Biological Supply Company. Call: 866-332-4478 to order.

Read all of the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely. Remember to observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activity. Clean up the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

Never conduct fieldwork on your own, especially in remote areas; always take a responsible partner with you. Prepare and leave a field safety plan, complete with planned survey locations and expected return time, with a responsible party. Wear appropriate clothing (long pants and close-toed shoes are usually best), sunblock, and insect repellant if necessary. Be familiar with the potential hazards in your chosen survey areas. Please review the “Field Work” portion of the Laboratory Safety Manual or your school’s specific safety guidelines for more information. Make sure that you are healthy enough to participate in fieldwork. If in doubt, consult your medical practitioner.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: What is the probability of an offspring with the genotype RRGg from the following cross?RrGG x Rrgg
If two heterozygous individuals produce four children, what is the probability that all the offspring will be heterozygous?

In a plant species, purple flower color (P) is dominant to white flower color (p), and flowering in the spring (F) is dominant to flowering in the summer (f). Which of the following describes the phenotype of a plant with the genotype PpFf?

options.text: a plant with purple flowers that blooms in the spring
a plant with purple flowers that blooms in the summer
a plant with white flowers that blooms in the spring
a plant with white flowers that blooms in the summer
a plant with pale purple flowers that blooms between spring and summer

You will plant corn seeds in the culture cups. You can plant your seeds in either collected soil, potting soil, or shredded paper towels. This will be the substrate. You will need approximately ½ cup of the substrate of your choice for each culture cup. Clean and sanitize the work space.
If collecting soil, remove any visible detritus (leaves, roots, twigs, dead bugs, etc.).

Make predictions about the genetic ratio of the offspring with both autosomal <button class='glossary-text'>recessive</button> and autosomal <button class='glossary-text'>dominant</button> modes of inheritance. Record your predictions in Data Table 1.
Pour seeds into the 250 mL beaker.
Pour bottled water over the seeds. Make sure the water level is at least three inches above the seeds. Your seeds will swell as they soak.
Allow your seeds to soak for 12-24 hours.
pageData.altText: Clock symbol

pageData.text: Note: Tap water may contain chlorine, which may adversely impact germination rates.

In this activity, you will plant your corn seeds prepared in the preparation section.  Once the seeds have been planted, you will be instructed to place the plants in a safe place and monitor daily for 7-10 days.

pages.title: Examination of the Intact Brain (4 steps)

pageData.text: Put your “substrate” in a bowl or container. Add some bottled water, and mix until the entire substrate is moist. Check the moisture level by conducting a pinch test. To conduct the pinch test, place a small amount of the mixed “substrate” between your thumb and forefinger. The substrate should clump together but not drip. If you add too much water and the substrate starts dripping, add more substrate.
Pour the water off the soaking corn seeds in the sink. You do not need to remove all of the water, and you should be careful to not drop any seeds down the drain.
Fill a culture cup approximately one-fourth to half full of the moist substrate. Reserve some to cover the seeds with a thin layer of substrate.
Put approximately 10 corn seeds on top of the substrate. Record the number of seeds that you put in the cup with a permanent marker on the side of the culture cup.
Cover the seeds with a thin layer of the reserved substrate from Step 2.
Repeat Steps 3–5 for the other culture cup.
Put the cups in a place where they will not be disturbed, preferably in a warm, sunny location (such as a windowsill).

Monitor the plants daily, and water them every other day, or as necessary. Do not allow the substrate to dry out. If the substrate becomes dry, this can negatively impact germination rates. Make sure the substrate stays moist. Seedlings should be visible approximately 5 days after planting. <button class='glossary-text'>Phenotypes</button> will be apparent between 7 and 10 days from planting.
Take a picture of your cups.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Note: If your paper towels covering the seeds begin to grow mold or become discolored, you can remove the shredded paper towels and replace them with new shredded paper towels. Once your seedlings begin to sprout and push up the top layer of shredded paper towels, you can remove them and discard into the household trash.
In this activity, you will measure the height of the plants and record them in your Lab Notebook.

pages.title: Examination of the Intact Brain (4 steps)

pageData.text: Once are visible, use the ruler and measure the height of the plant (from soil level). Record the height and your observations in Data Table 1.
Take a picture of your seedlings.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: In this activity, you will perform a chi-square test to determine the likelihood that your observed data correlates well with expected data.

pages.title: Examination of the Intact Brain (4 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
  Data Analysis and Chi-Square Test

typeBefore.title:
A
  Data Analysis and Chi-Square Test
typeBefore.subTitle: Chi-Square Statistics

typeBefore.text: The chi-square goodness of fit test is a calculation that allows you to determine the likelihood that the observed data correlates with expected data. The null hypothesis states that the difference found between expected results and the actual results was due to chance occurrence. The chi-square test will allow you to conclude whether the null hypothesis should be rejected or accepted. The chi-square equation is:
x<sup class='bodySupscript'>2</sup> = (observed value – expected value)<sup class='bodySupscript'>2</sup>/(expected value)
The chi-square test calculates two statistical measures:
1. The deviation between your observed numbers and your expected numbers.
2. The probability that the deviation is due to chance or that the deviation is statistically significant.
Example: You have 40 pea seeds, and the expected ratio is that ¾ (0.75) of them will be green and ¼ (0.25) of them will be yellow.

Multiple 40 times 0.75, which equals 30. It is then predicted that 30 of the peas should be green. This means 10 peas should be yellow. After germination, suppose 35 of the plants were green and only 5 were yellow. The observed ratio of green plants is 35/40 (0.875) and 5/40 (0.125) for yellow plants. For green peas, the expected value is 30, while the observed value was 35.

To calculate the deviation, take the observed value minus the expected value. In this case, the deviation is 35-30, which equals 5. You will then find the deviation squared by squaring this value, giving us 25. Finally, you will calculate the deviation squared divided by the expected value. In this case, 25 divided by 30 equals 0.83.
The chi-squared value is the sum of the deviation squared divided by the expected value for all of the <button class='glossary-text'>phenotypes</button>.
Watch the following video on the chi-squared analysis:

pageData.text: Determine the ratio of phenotypes you expected in the F2 generation. Record your results in Data Table 2.
Determine the ratio of phenotypes you observed in the F2 generation. Record your results in Data Table 3.
Complete Data Table 4 for “e” and “o” values, using the actual numbers of each phenotype, not ratios or percentages.

To determine whether the chi-square value rejects or fails to reject the standard null hypothesis, you must first determine the degrees of freedom (df) associated with the data. Degrees of freedom is a measure of how many categories are in the experiment. For genetic tests such as these, the number of degrees of freedom is one less than the number of phenotypic categories. Calculate the degrees of freedom and record the results in Data Table 5.

Decide whether to accept or reject the null hypothesis. Using the chi-square distribution table in Table 4, determine the probability that the deviation is due to chance. If the probability value is 5% or greater, then your results support the null hypothesis. There is no difference between the observed and expected values of the null hypothesis, and/or if there is a slight difference, it is caused by chance and chance alone. If the probability value is less than 5%, then you can reject the null hypothesis and conclude that the difference between your results and the expected result is statistically significant and likely not due only to chance.
In this activity, you will continue to monitor your plants over several more days to determine whether certain traits are lethal or non-lethal to the plants.

pages.title: Examination of the Intact Brain (4 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
  Non-Lethal vs. Lethal Traits Observations

typeBefore.title:
A
  Non-Lethal vs. Lethal Traits Observations

pageData.text: Continue to monitor and water the plants. Plants that cannot perform photosynthesis quickly exhaust their embryonic food source, the endosperm. Survival of these plants beyond 14 days requires a complex external nutrition delivery system. Record how long the albino plants were able to survive in Data Table 1.
Take a picture of your plants.

pageData.altText: A procedural workflow for the investigation. Before beginning, you will need to prepare the substrate, predict the genetic ratios of the offspring and soak the seeds overnight. In Activity 1, you will mix the substrate and water. Then, you will add the substrate to the cups, add the seeds and place the cups in sunlight to monitor. Next, you will photograph the cups. In Activity 2, you will measure the seedling heights and photograph the seedlings. In Activity 3, you will determine the expected ratio and calculate the expected ratio of the seedlings. Then, you will determine the Chi-squared value. Next, you will calculate the degrees of freedom and accept or reject the null hypothesis. In Activity 4, you will continue to observe the seedlings. Once 14 days have elapsed, you will record the days of survival for each plant and photograph the seedlings.

data.title: Allele
data.content: One of two or more versions of a gene

data.title: Dominant
data.content: Describes the trait that is expressed when two different alleles are present

data.title: F generation
data.content: Offspring of the P generation; “F” stands for filial

data.title: Genotype
data.content: The genetic makeup of an individual cell or organism that determines or contributes to the phenotype

data.title: Heterozygous
data.content: Describes a genotype in which two different alleles are inherited

data.title: Homozygous dominant
data.content: Describes a genotype in which both of the alleles that are inherited are for the dominant trait

data.title: Homozygous recessive
data.content: Describes a genotype in which both of the alleles that are inherited are for the recessive trait

data.title: Law of independent assortment
data.content: Mendel's second law which states that all traits are inherited independently of one another

data.title: Law of segregation
data.content: Mendel's first law which states that individuals possess two alleles for each trait

data.title: P generation
data.content: The first two organisms that are crossed; “P” stands for parental

data.title: Phenotype
data.content: The physical expression of a trait

data.title: Punnett square
data.content: A diagram used to show the potential results of genetic crosses

data.title: Recessive
data.content: Describes the trait that not is expressed when two different alleles are present
